So I don't know if that lawsuit was holding up a merger and acquisition or holding up the company from doing anything. But it's important that they're lawsuit free and the head of the company's lawsuit free going into anything that they could do. The other thing I would mention is the last time Ryan Cohen bought in was I believe right before the shareholders meeting last year in 2023, would have been right here. He had about 10 million with the GameStop in 2022. And then 10 million with the GameStop in 2023, he hasn't bought any GameStop since. And I think it's a hard ask for him to ask his shareholders, hey, I'm going to dilute us 39, which they just did. But then I'm not going to put my own money where my mouth is.

text: just described right here this basically gives them not infinite liquidity but near infinite just like we saw go ahead just a quick note on the the hedging puts the way that you're talking about hedging that is what we would call like a bit of a pure hedge there's a lot of other ways that they can hedge that position now and I think it's important just to flag that again it doesn't impact this too much I do see a lot of people apply the very strict approach of hedging with pure hedges and the reason why I bring that up is because it oversimplifies a little bit about the the way that market makers are going to manage their book and it's never predicated on one single position it's always predicated on the entire book of positions across all products right just a worthwhile note nothing incorrect at all but just something other people should be aware of perfect and then I'll say the last one the most the one we know the least about is right swaps so what is a swap you know a swap is a derivative contract between a party and a counter party if it's an equity total return swap and it's to the downside you're betting that the stock is going to go down right so you could get huge exposure to game stock to the downside um what's the counter party going to do they're going to hedge that position
